moves.1. e4 c5 2. c3 d6 3. d4: That's what I usually play against Sicilian. I found the d6 variation lest scary, cause it just gives me the pawn center and the game is usually calm.
moves.3... cxd4 4. cxd4 e5:
Surprised! Here I could just take on e5 and then exchange the queens. That would give me some positional advantage due to black not having a castle. 
However, I wanted a deeper game with bigger dominance after a while.
moves.5. Nf3: The idea of this move is that after 5... exd4 6. Nxd4 black has an isolated and bacward pawn on d6.
moves.5... Bg4 6. dxe5: Now I take, cause the exchange of queens would lead to a pawn mire for me.
moves.6... Bxf3: This is the only way for black to save their pawn. However, It leads to an open position where I have two bishops.
moves.7. gxf3: I don't decide where my queen would be and also have the idea to play on the g-file.
moves.7... Qa5+: Black wants to save his opportunity for castle, but that just leads to development for me.
moves.8. Bd2 Qxe5 9. Bc3: A key move. Places my bishop on a big diagonal, while saving my b2 pawn.
moves.9... Qc5 10. Rg1: By attacking on g7, I aim to fix black's pieces and interfere their development. F6 just leads to even slower development, so there is only one move left.
moves.10... Nf6: Notice how black couldn't develop his bishop on e7 or after g6 on g7, cause I would take either on g7 or f6.
moves.12... Qb6 13. Nc4 Qc7: Black is underdeveloped, while my pieces are quite positioned. I hadn't decided where to place my f1 bishop. Then it came to my mind that my rook stands good against my opponents queen. I decided to try to open the c file and see what happens.
moves.14. b4 O-O-O: Well, it wasn't clear how castle king-side would happen, so that seems to be the thing. However, I think that 14.. a6 needed more attention. Maybe 15. a4 b5 16. Na5
moves.15. Bh3+: Developed with tempo and on a big diagonal. Also, now all my pieces except my g1 rook are turned to the queenside.
moves.16... d5: Surprise! Still, it isn't clear if that would lead to developing the f8 bishop. Usually, opening the center is bad when underdeveloped. But a precise game is needed, to opose that move.
moves.17. bxc6 dxc4: Now it seems that I should move my queen and lose the c6 pawn. But thats the cost for a good queen-side attack.
moves.18. Qa4:
Now if 18... bxc6 19. Ba5 
So the move seems to be 18... Qxc6 with unclear game.
moves.18... Qxh2: But that forces the ending. Eating pawns when under attack might be bad for your health.
moves.19. Qb5 Qc7:
If 19... b6 20. Be5+ and black loses his queen. 
If 19... Qxg1+ 20. Ke2 and the mate is hardly evadable. Even if so, the blacks queen is dead.
moves.21. Rxc4:
The pawn is returned, but there is something more. 
If 21... b6 22. Bxd6 Rxd6 (22... Qxd6 23. c7+) 23. e5
moves.22. cxb7: After black move his queen, there will be Rc8+ and promoting with double check. The rest is just dying.

gameName: Why not to castle queenside when with black in Sicilian and some other stuff
